--- title: "Time Series and Econometric Analysis" execute: warning: false freeze: true cache: true format: html: html-math-method: katex code-block-bg: "#E5E7E9" df-print: paged code-overflow : wrap code-copy : true --- ## Introduction ### Resources - Time series analysis by James D Hamilton - its considered to be the bible on time series analysis, pretty much covers all the theory , it doesnt have any code or pseudocode - Introduction to Time Series with R by Metcalfe & Coweperwait - Analysis of Financial Time Series by Tsay ### Aim and Motivation - Would be exploring time series analysis in the context of finance - Implementing code from the books above later 2 books mentioned above, would be using the book by Hamilton as reference - Aim to understand different time series models in R. - (Will keep on adding the aims as is go on) ## Financial Time Series and Linear Time series ### Asset Returns ::: {#def-Simple_gross_return} ## Simple gross return
Arithmetic Returns $$P_t = P_{t-1}(1+R_t) \implies R_t = \frac{P_t - P_{t-1}}{P_t}$$ where $P_t$ and $R_t$ are the price and return at time $t$ respectively
Continuously compounded return or log return $$r_t = \ln(1+R_t)$$
Dividend Payment $$r_t = \ln(P_t + D_t) -\ln(P_{t-1})$$ Where $D_t$ is dividend payment between time t-1 and time t . :::
::: {#def-Multiperiod_simple_return} ## Multiperiod gross return
Similiary we can define multiperiod simple return by $$ R_t[k] = exp{[\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=0}^{k-1}(1+R_{t-j})]} -1$$ where exp is the exponentential function and k is total number periods the asset was held for. Log return would be $$ r_t[k] = r_t +r_{t-1}+.....+r_{t-k+1}$$ ::: ::: {#def-Portfolio_return} ## Portfolio Return $$R_{p,t}= \sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i R_{it}$$ Where $p$ is the portfolio , $i$ the ith asset and $w_i$ the weight of the ith asset in the portofolio ::: [* Load data and header =T give the 1st row of the data file , that is the names of the cloumns of the data set ]{.aside} ::: {.cell code-block-border-right='false' hash='time_series_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_5f454dd171078270159db11d2cc6f3dc'} ```{.r .cell-code} # da contains the return for 5 five stocks and indexes namely IBM ,value-weighted , equal-weighted and S&P composite index from 1970 to 2008 library(fBasics) da = read.table("TST/d-ibm3dx7008.txt",header = T) dim(da) # dimensions for the data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 9845 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} da[1:5,] ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} tail(da)#first row ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ibm = da[,2] # IBM simple returns sibm = ibm*100 #Percentage simple returns basicStats(sibm) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} s1 = skewness(sibm) t = s1/sqrt(6/9845) #defintion for test statistic here 9845 is N t ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.487093 attr(,"method") [1] "moment" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} pv = 2*(1-pnorm(t)) # Calculate p-value pv ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.01287919 attr(,"method") [1] "moment" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2" hash='time_series_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_1c8afad8c2c36a24f95519a541f00a55'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ibm = as.data.frame(da[,1:2]) ibm["log_return"] = log(1+ibm["rtn"]) colnames(ibm)[2] <- "simple_return" ggplot(ibm,aes(x = simple_return,colour = "Emperical"))+ggtitle("Simple return distribution") + xlim (-0.15,0.15)+geom_density()+stat_function(mapping = aes(colour = "Normal"), fun = dnorm,args = with(ibm,c(mean =mean(simple_return),sd = sd(simple_return)))) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](time_series_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(ibm,aes(x = log_return,colour = "Emperical"))+ggtitle("Log return distribution") + xlim (-0.15,0.15)+geom_density()+ stat_function(mapping = aes(colour = "Normal"), fun = dnorm,args = with(ibm,c(mean = mean(log_return),sd = sd(log_return))))+ scale_x_continuous("log return distribution",limits = c(-0.15,0.15)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](time_series_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #stat_function( #fun = dnorm,args = with(ibm,c(mean =mean(simple_return),sd = sd(simple_return))))+ ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='time_series_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_2c3a2fd595ce60c46e34ba2ffa27619e'} ```{.r .cell-code} ibm1 = ibm[, 2] plot(ibm1,type = 'l') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](time_series_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ibm2 = ts(ibm1,frequency = 250 ,start = c(1970,1)) plot.ts(ibm2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](time_series_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} acf(ibm1,lag =250,ylim= c(-0.05,0.05)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](time_series_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} acf(ibm2,lag=250,ylim= c(-0.05,0.05)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](time_series_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-4.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Linear Time Series :::{#def-Stationarity} ## Stationarity Foundation of time series analysis is Stationarity. A time series $\{r_t\}$ is said to be strictly stationary if the joint distribution of $(r_{t_{1}},r_{t_{2}},r_{t_{3}},....,r_{t_{k}})$ is identical to that of $(r_{t_{1+t}},r_{t_{2+t}},r_{t_{3+t}},....,r_{t_{k+t}})$ for all $t$ , where $k$ is an arbitrary positive integer and $(t_1,t_2,t_3,....,t_k)$ is collection of $k$ positive integers. Strict stationarity is very hard to verify emperically
A time series is said to be weakly stationary if the mean of $r_t$ and the covariance between $r_t$ and $r_{t-l}$ are time invariant where $l$ is an arbitrary integer. Weak stationarity enables us to make inference cooncerning future observations Weak stationarity is commonly studied and more practical. The covariance $\gamma_l = Cov(r_t,r_{t-l})$ is called the lag-$l$ autocovariance of $r_t$. From the above defintion it follows that * $\gamma_0=Var(r_t)$ * $\gamma_{-l} = \gamma_l$ :::
